name: Rural Electrification Planning
description: A rural region in a developing country with 50,000 residents currently has limited access to electricity. Only 30% of households have grid connection, and frequent power outages affect economic development. The government has allocated funding to improve energy access and reliability. This decision involves selecting the most appropriate electrification strategy considering local resources, economic constraints, and community needs.

learning_objectives: Understand energy access challenges in developing regions
Consider social and economic development factors
metadata.data_sources: Based on rural electrification studies and development project reports

units.Households Served: Number of households with reliable electricity access
units.Local Job Creation: Direct and indirect jobs created in the region
units.Technical Complexity: Score 1-10 (10=most complex to implement and maintain)

assumptions: Government priority: Universal energy access by 2030
discussion_points: How do development priorities differ from commercial energy decisions?
What role should community participation play in technology selection?
How important is local job creation versus technical efficiency?
Should solutions prioritize immediate access or long-term sustainability?
How do financing constraints affect technology choices?
What are the social impacts of different electrification approaches?

alternative_descriptions.Grid Extension: Extend the national electricity grid to reach all unconnected communities in the region
alternative_descriptions.Mini-Grid Solar: Install community-scale solar mini-grids (50-200 kW) to serve village clusters
alternative_descriptions.Individual Solar Home Systems: Distribute individual solar systems (50-200W) to households not served by grid
alternative_descriptions.Micro-Hydroelectric: Develop small-scale hydroelectric systems (10-100 kW) using local water resources
alternative_descriptions.Biomass Gasification: Install biomass gasification plants using agricultural waste and local biomass
alternative_descriptions.Hybrid Renewable System: Combine solar, wind, and battery storage in community-scale hybrid systems

criteria_descriptions.Implementation Cost: Total cost including equipment, installation, infrastructure, and capacity building
criteria_descriptions.Households Served: Number of households that will gain reliable electricity access
criteria_descriptions.Reliability: Consistency and availability of electricity supply throughout the year
criteria_descriptions.Local Job Creation: Employment opportunities created for local residents during and after implementation
criteria_descriptions.Environmental Impact: Positive environmental effects including reduced indoor air pollution and deforestation
criteria_descriptions.Technical Complexity: Level of technical expertise required for installation, operation, and maintenance
criteria_descriptions.Community Acceptance: Level of community support and willingness to adopt the technology

key_insights: Rural electrification requires different criteria than urban energy planning
Community acceptance and local capacity are critical success factors
Job creation can be as important as technical performance
Environmental benefits include health improvements from reduced indoor pollution
Financing constraints often favor lower-cost, simpler solutions
extension_activities: Research actual rural electrification projects in different countries
Interview community members about their energy priorities
Calculate cost per household served for each alternative
Design a community consultation process for technology selection
Explore innovative financing mechanisms for rural energy projects
related_sdgs: SDG 8: Decent Work and Economic Growth
